column1: LEGO 76079 (along with the other Guardians of the Galaxy: Volume 2 sets) is finally here! My thoughts? Read on!
The main builds of this set are Taserface'
column3: ship and a piece of forest scenery. While the ship does feature four stud shooters mounted onto the top and bottom of the model, which adds to play, I do feel that the overall build is lacking in display value, with the majority of&nbsp
column4: studs left exposed, and a blocky finished product.

column1: The colors are nice, with the transition from the dark bluish grey of the wings leading into black plates, and eventually the Ravager red. Obviously, the Taserface
column2: minifigure can be easily placed into the cockpit of the ship.

column1: The vehicle also features a clip on the rear end to store a blaster.
The piece of scenery definitely adds to the overall playability of this set. The tree build looks satisfying for such a small set, and the Gatling gun styled

My favorite aspect of the build is definitely the little Milano wing that is attached to the tree via ball point. It looks fantastic, and really sets up a scenario of the Milano having crashed onto this planet.

The line up of characters that this set offers is nothing shy of fantastic. Each figure is 100% exclusive (for now) to 76079, which makes this set a must buy for fans, as it includes the new Guardians member Mantis, as well as the excellently designed Taserface and an updated Rocket Raccoon.

The Rocket figure included in this set is a drastic departure from the 2014 version of the character, which sported a bright orange costume and a blank mouth design. This 2017 redesign looks even better than the original figure in my opinion, which to me is a trait that many of the redesigned Guardians seem to lack. Rocket'
column2: s torso is reddish brown, and includes some extremely detailed dark blue and dark bluish grey detailing on the torso, which depicts various zippers and buckles. Rocket&#39
column3: s short legs are also dark blue, and the same tail the figure came with in 2014 is included with this set as well.

column1: Rocket also features a wide, cocky smirk on his face, which is an excellent addition to the figure. Two brick built pistols are included for Rocket to wield.
The Mantis figure utilizes a brand new rubberized hairpiece, which allows for the character'
column2: s thin antennae to be molded to the hairpiece. Mantis features two facial expressions, one featuring a kind smile, and the other showcasing a crazed aggressive expression.
s torso is very detailed, and features contrasts between light and dark green, which I think looks fantastic. Mantis&#39

column1: Taserface is a character that, I will admit, I know nothing about, although judging by the torso print, it seems he may be a member of Yondu'
column4: which is printed with sunken in yellow eyes, and various scar details. The figure uses a common beard piece in black, and a hairpiece that, if I&#39
column5: m not mistaken, has only ever been used by an Orc minifigure from the Hobbit theme.

column1: The figure also features some substantial leg printing, depicting various straps and padding. Lastly, Taserface wields a large, brickbuilt
column2: rocket launcher that is built off of a stud shooter.

column1: The Superheroes line always has fantastic $20 sets, and 76079: Ravager Attack is certainly no different. While Taserface'
column2: s ship may be a little lacking in terms of displayability and collectability, I feel the play &nbsp
column3: value is solid enough to warrant a pass. The terrain build is exceptional, and the 3 exclusive minifigures add even more value to this set. Overall, I&#39
column4: d say that while this set is definitely not the best Guardians 2 set, it is one that is worth checking out, as it features some solid builds, and fantastic figures. I&#39

column1: ,TRUE,3,2,3,4,5 Odeinoichus","2017-08-25T15:21:17.163Z","Oh no, it's Taserface... Yeah, not taking that seriously.","
column13: > Guardians of the Galaxy Volume Two receives three new LEGO sets and a single polybag managing to present the crew and every key element of the film with exception to the one huge antagonist that has not appeared as a LEGO set yet. It does manage to capture the fun of the sequel though and we do get quite a lot of fun models in these sets. This is the smallest price-point and it&rsquo
column14: s a strong outing, the reasons why will be discussed during the review.

column8: >Box: The Marvel Super Heroes box design hasn&rsquo
column10: ve had the same colour and same general design of imagery that showcases the sets and the play features for the past five years and I highly doubt that&rsquo
column11: s going to change much. The Guardians are in the upper corner and the logo is in the bottom corner making it very clear which MCU film these sets represent.

column8: >Instructions: The set is broken up between two numbered bags, the manual however is a single booklet with all of the necessary steps in one convenient location compared to other sets in the Theme. They are fairly standard and what we&rsquo
column9: ve come to expect from LEGO Instruction Manuals
column10: the modular nature of the build means there are fairly easy steps to follow and a page in the back shows all three sets.

column9: s also a comic book included which does a great silent LEGO humour approach to showing the story that plays out with these three sets.

column8: >Honestly this is a pretty dull set for parts, there is nothing truly unique or eye catching awesome, however MOC fans might find some pretty big uses for the parts since most of them are pretty generic and the use of stickers mean that there are no printed elements in this set, with exception to the small control panel section for Taserface&rsquo

>Mantis: One of the newest Guardians, Mantis features a dual-sided torso print of her movie outfit, which makes a nice dark green suit, she has bare arms and black gloves, with a double-sided facial print featuring a calm and serene expression and an angrier &lsquo
column9: I am about to murder you&rsquo
column10: expression. Her hair piece is quite unique and is a softer rubbery plastic which fits quite snugly on her head.

column8: >Sadly she has no accessories, although this is accurate to the film in which she had no accessories.

>Rocket: This is the fourth official Rocket Minifigure made, this version is dressed in his new outfit and features a new grinning smile on his head piece print, he includes two weapons both using the &lsquo
column10: piece with added elements to enhance their look overall. A fun little mini-fig and definitely a must have for Rocket fans.

column8: >Taserface: The best and biggest joke of GotG V2, this non-villain is dressed in a Ravager outfit, decked all in red with impressive costume printing on his legs, double-sided torso and head, which is covered up slightly by his super long black beard. He includes a massive cannon built out of bricks all using the stud launcher piece as a base so you can launch studs at the Guardians.
>He also features a new hair piece which completes the look of the Fear Inducing Taserface! Now everyone continue to laugh mockingly at this pathetic wannabe super villain.
>Bag 1: Mantis and Taserface begin to do battle against one another while the Ravager&rsquo
column9: s ship model is begun to be built. This section of the build is pretty straight forward and doesn&rsquo
column10: t strike me as difficult for younger builders. The ship itself is a nice red, black and grey colour combination that looks good. No stickers will be used during this bag&rsquo

column8: >Bag 2: Rocket joins Mantis to defend against Taserface, his ship is completed here and stickers will now be placed for detailing, on both the ship and the secondary tree model with wrecked portions of the Milano. This build is also really simple and easy to get through though, which makes sense for a set of this size range. There really isn&rsquo
column9: t any techniques used that do anything different or unique that would upset or frustrate the younger builders.
s Ship: This model is the larger of the two in the set and represents a smaller craft, roughly fighter-like in design and function. It&rsquo
column10: s a small one-man vehicle loaded with four stud launchers to attack the Guardians
column11: a very fun model for playing with, it&rsquo
column12: s great just swooshing this around for KFOLs or AFOLs. The overall shape and design reminds me of a bow or boomerang, a very distinctive design, there&rsquo
column13: s also storage for one weapon in the back on a clip. In case you lose the other accessory Taserface comes with.

column8: >Defense Platform: This is basically a small tree with pieces of the wrecked Milano added, a large six-stud launcher graces one side of the tree to blow Taserface away and the wing attached on the opposite side is meant for&hellip
column9: defense? Maybe Rocket crouches down behind it to launch energy blasts from his two guns. Overall a bit of a lacking build, we&rsquo
column10: ve seen and built many trees before in similar fashion, it might have been nicer to get a small bunker shaped construction using parts of the Milano. Either way it isn&rsquo
column11: t accurate to the scene as shown in the film.

column8: >For the asking price and the size of the set I&rsquo
column9: d say this is a pretty good offering from LEGO&rsquo
column10: s MCU sets this year. The ship and small defensive area don&rsquo
column11: t look like much when put side to side considering the Nova Corps ship from the first movie was a larger design. However I&rsquo
column12: d say this is a pretty good set, it includes two brand new characters and some fun play elements, you&rsquo
column13: ll definitely want this set if you&rsquo
column14: re a fan of GotG so I&rsquo
column15: d say this is recommended. The strength of that recommendation depends purely on how much you enjoy Guardians of the Galaxy Volume Two.
